title: The moon illusion - Andrew Vanden Heuvel

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon where the full moon appears larger when it's near the horizon compared to when it's high overhead?

options.label: A
options.text: The Ebbinghaus Illusion

options.label: B
options.text: The Ponzo Illusion

options.label: C
options.text: Convergence Micropsia

options.label: D
options.text: The Moon Illusion

options.label: A
options.text: The Ebbinghaus Illusion

options.label: B
options.text: The Ponzo Illusion

options.label: C
options.text: Convergence Micropsia

options.label: D
options.text: Atmospheric Refraction

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It disappears

options.label: D
options.text: It is reversed

options.label: A
options.text: The Ebbinghaus Illusion

options.label: B
options.text: The Ponzo Illusion

options.label: C
options.text: Convergence Micropsia

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: What is déjà vu? What is déjà vu? - Michael Molina

multiple-choice.question: What is déjà vu, and how is it characterized?

options.label: A
options.text: A feeling of familiarity that is based on a past experience.

options.label: B
options.text: A feeling of familiarity that is not based on a past experience.

options.label: C
options.text: A feeling of confusion that occurs when the brain processes information too quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: A feeling of excitement that occurs when the brain encounters something new.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult for scientists to study déjà vu?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a rare occurrence.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has no physical manifestations and occurs without notice.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a complex phenomenon that requires advanced technology to study.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not a legitimate area of scientific study.

multiple-choice.question: According to the dual processing theory, what causes déjà vu?

options.label: A
options.text: A delay in information from one of the brain's pathways.

options.label: B
options.text: A confusion of the past and present.

options.label: C
options.text: A failure to identify a familiar object.

options.label: D
options.text: A distraction that causes the brain to subliminally take in an environment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the hologram theory of déjà vu, and how does it explain the phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: The theory states that memories are stored in the form of holograms, and déjà vu occurs when the brain summons up a memory without identifying it.

options.label: B
options.text: The theory states that déjà vu occurs when the brain processes information too quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: The theory states that déjà vu occurs when the brain is distracted by a particular object.

options.label: D
options.text: The theory states that déjà vu occurs when the brain is experiencing a lack of oxygen.

multiple-choice.question: According to the divided attention theory, what causes déjà vu?

options.label: A
options.text: A delay in information from one of the brain's pathways.

options.label: B
options.text: A confusion of the past and present.

options.label: C
options.text: A distraction that causes the brain to subliminally take in an environment.

options.label: D
options.text: A failure to identify a familiar object.

title: How to learn? From mistakes - Diana Laufenberg

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main point about the current state of education?

options.label: A
options.text: That students need to focus more on standardized testing to succeed.

options.label: B
options.text: That the current system values information scarcity over experiential learning.

options.label: C
options.text: That teachers should be more authoritarian in the classroom.

options.label: D
options.text: That technology has no place in education.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the speaker's experiment with her 12th-grade students, where she asked them to put on an election forum for their community?

options.label: A
options.text: The students were uninterested and did not participate.

options.label: B
options.text: The students were unable to complete the task without significant guidance.

options.label: C
options.text: The students successfully produced an election forum booklet and invited the community to attend.

options.label: D
options.text: The students were only interested in the topic of government because of the speaker's enthusiasm.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: She began to incorporate more experiential learning and authentic experiences into her teaching.

options.label: C
options.text: She became more authoritarian in the classroom and less willing to listen to student feedback.

options.label: D
options.text: She stopped using technology in the classroom altogether.

options.label: A
options.text: To teach students about the importance of genocide awareness.

options.label: B
options.text: To help students develop their critical thinking skills through film analysis.

options.label: C
options.text: To encourage students to reflect on their own values and goals.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide students with an opportunity to practice their filmmaking skills.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with the current culture of education, which emphasizes "one right answer" and standardized testing?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows students to develop their critical thinking skills and creativity.

options.label: B
options.text: It prepares students for the workforce by teaching them to follow instructions and complete tasks efficiently.

options.label: C
options.text: It does not allow for student failure and experimentation, which are essential to the learning process.

options.label: D
options.text: It places too much emphasis on teacher feedback and not enough on student self-assessment.

options.text: The molecules must hit each other in the right orientation and with enough energy.

options.label: D
options.text: The molecules must be in a solid state.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a chemical reaction that can only happen in one direction?

options.label: A
options.text: Burning

options.label: B
options.text: Rusting

options.label: C
options.text: Decomposition

options.label: D
options.text: Photosynthesis

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the rate of forward and reverse reactions over time in a system that reaches equilibrium?

options.label: A
options.text: The rate of forward reactions increases, and the rate of reverse reactions decreases.

options.label: B
options.text: The rate of forward reactions decreases, and the rate of reverse reactions increases.

options.label: C
options.text: The rates of forward and reverse reactions become equal.

options.label: D
options.text: The rates of forward and reverse reactions both decrease to zero.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the state of a system where the population numbers of different states no longer change over time?

options.label: A
options.text: Equilibrium

options.label: B
options.text: Steady state

options.label: C
options.text: Chemical reaction

options.label: D
options.text: Molecular stability

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a non-chemical system that can exhibit equilibrium behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: Gene pools

options.label: B
options.text: Highway traffic

options.label: C
options.text: Weather patterns

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B

title: A brief history of plural word...s - John McWhorter

multiple-choice.question: What was unique about the way plurals were formed in Old English?

options.label: A
options.text: All plurals were formed by adding -s to the end of the word.

options.label: B
options.text: Plurals were formed by changing the vowel sound in the word.

options.label: C
options.text: Plurals were formed in a variety of ways, including adding different sounds to the end of the word.

options.label: D
options.text: Plurals were not used in Old English.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the Vikings' influence on the English language lead to a simplification of plurals?

options.label: A
options.text: The Vikings were skilled linguists who wanted to simplify the language.

options.label: B
options.text: The Vikings were not good at learning languages and found the complex plurals of Old English difficult to master.

options.label: C
options.text: The Vikings wanted to impose their own language, Norse, on the English population.

options.label: D
options.text: The Vikings had no influence on the English language.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a plural form that has survived from Old English?

options.label: A
options.text: Children

options.label: B
options.text: Sheep

options.label: C
options.text: Oxen

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the result of the Vikings' influence on the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: The language became more complex and difficult to learn.

options.label: B
options.text: The language was replaced by Norse.

options.label: C
options.text: The language was simplified, with plurals becoming more regular.

options.label: D
options.text: The language was unaffected by the Vikings' influence.

multiple-choice.question: Why do we still have some irregular plurals in Modern English?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Vikings did not influence the language enough to change all the plurals.

options.label: B
options.text: Because some words were used so frequently that their irregular plural forms were retained.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the language was influenced by other languages that had irregular plurals.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the language has not evolved enough to simplify all plurals.

title: What is dyslexia? - Kelli Sandman-Hurley

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of dyslexia?

options.label: A
options.text: A visual processing problem

options.label: B
options.text: A phonological processing problem

options.label: C
options.text: A memory recall issue

options.label: D
options.text: A comprehension problem

multiple-choice.question: How do people with dyslexia often spell words?

options.label: A
options.text: By breaking down words into parts

options.label: B
options.text: By sounding out words phonetically

options.label: C
options.text: By memorizing words

options.label: D
options.text: By using visual aids

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of neurodiversity?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that all brains are identical in structure and function

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that all brains show differences in structure and function

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that dyslexia is a pathological disorder

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that people with dyslexia are defective

multiple-choice.question: Which part of the brain is generally in charge of language and reading?

options.label: A
options.text: Right hemisphere

options.label: B
options.text: Left hemisphere

options.label: C
options.text: Frontal lobe

options.label: D
options.text: Cerebellum

multiple-choice.question: What type of intervention can help people with dyslexia improve their reading?

options.label: A
options.text: A visual-based intervention

options.label: B
options.text: A phonics-based intervention

options.label: C
options.text: An intensive, multi-sensory intervention

options.label: D

title: The infinite life of pi - Reynaldo Lopes

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the circumference and diameter of a circle?

options.label: A
options.text: The circumference is always twice the diameter.

options.label: B
options.text: The circumference is always half the diameter.

options.label: C
options.text: The ratio of the circumference to the diameter is always the same number.

options.label: D
options.text: The circumference and diameter are unrelated.

multiple-choice.question: How did ancient mathematicians estimate the value of pi?

options.label: A
options.text: By inscribing triangles in circles.

options.label: B
options.text: By inscribing polygons in circles.

options.label: C
options.text: By calculating the area of a circle.

options.label: D
options.text: By calculating the volume of a sphere.

multiple-choice.question: What is the nature of the number pi?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a rational number that can be expressed as a ratio of two whole numbers.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an irrational number that can never be expressed as a ratio of two whole numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a transcendental number that is not related to any mathematical operation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a complex number that has both real and imaginary parts.

multiple-choice.question: How many digits of pi have been calculated using quantum computers?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 1 million digits.

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 1 billion digits.

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 2 quadrillion digits.

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 10 quadrillion digits.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the scientific uses of pi in statistics?

options.label: A
options.text: Calculating the area of a triangle.

options.label: B
options.text: Calculating the volume of a sphere.

options.label: C
options.text: Calculating the area under a normal distribution curve.

options.label: D
options.text: Calculating the margin of error in scientific results.

title: Comma story - Terisa Folaron

multiple-choice.question: What is the acronym used to remember the conjunctions in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: FANBOYS

options.label: B
options.text: SUBORD

options.label: C
options.text: COMMA

options.label: D
options.text: SENTENCE

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of subordinates in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: To connect two equal clauses

options.label: B
options.text: To connect two unequal clauses

options.label: C
options.text: To separate two independent clauses

options.label: D
options.text: To separate two dependent clauses

multiple-choice.question: When a subordinate begins a sentence, where does the comma place itself?

options.label: A
options.text: Before the subordinate

options.label: B
options.text: After the first thought or complete sentence

options.label: C
options.text: After the subordinate

options.label: D
options.text: At the end of the sentence

multiple-choice.question: What is the rule for using commas with conjunctions?

options.label: A
options.text: The comma always comes after the conjunction

options.label: B
options.text: The comma always comes before the conjunction

options.label: C
options.text: The comma is not needed with conjunctions

options.label: D
options.text: The comma is only needed with fanboys

multiple-choice.question: In what scenario does a conjunction not need the help of a comma?

options.label: A
options.text: When connecting two complete sentences

options.label: B
options.text: When connecting a complete sentence and a fragment sentence

options.label: C
options.text: When connecting two fragment sentences

options.label: D
options.text: When connecting two independent clauses

title: What is an aurora? - Michael Molina

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate speed at which matter is blasted from the Sun?

options.label: A
options.text: 100,000 miles per hour

options.label: B
options.text: 1 million miles per hour

options.label: C
options.text: 10 million miles per hour

options.label: D
options.text: 100 million miles per hour

options.label: B
options.text: Magnetosphere

options.label: C
options.text: Atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: Solar Wind

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Magnetic Storm

options.label: D
options.text: Aurora

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: 20-200 miles above the surface

options.label: C
options.text: 1,000-2,000 miles above the surface

options.label: D
options.text: 10,000-20,000 miles above the surface

multiple-choice.question: What is responsible for the green and red colors in the northern and southern lights?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Excited oxygen atoms

options.label: C
options.text: Solar wind

options.label: D
options.text: Magnetic field

title: Inside your computer - Bettina Bair

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the CPU (Central Processing Unit) in a computer?

options.label: A
options.text: To manage the computer's memory

options.label: B
options.text: To handle input/output operations

options.label: C
options.text: To fetch instructions from memory and execute them

options.label: D
options.text: To provide power to the computer's components

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the CPU receives an interrupt from the I/O subsystem?

options.label: A
options.text: It ignores the interrupt and continues executing instructions

options.label: B
options.text: It immediately executes the instructions associated with the interrupt

options.label: C
options.text: It saves its current state and executes the instructions associated with the interrupt

options.label: D
options.text: It shuts down the computer

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of compiling a program written in a human-readable programming language?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the program more readable to humans

options.label: B
options.text: To make the program more efficient in terms of memory usage

options.label: C
options.text: To convert the program into a format that the computer can understand

options.label: D
options.text: To add more features to the program

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the basic input/output subsystem in a computer?

options.label: A
options.text: To manage the computer's memory

options.label: B
options.text: To handle input/output operations and act as a buffer to the CPU

options.label: C
options.text: To execute instructions from memory

options.label: D
options.text: To provide power to the computer's components

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the CPU needs instructions for how to deal with a mouse click?

options.label: A
options.text: It generates an interrupt to the I/O subsystem

options.label: B
options.text: It looks up the address for the mouse program and sends a request to the memory subsystem

options.label: C
options.text: It executes the instructions associated with the mouse click

options.label: D
options.text: It shuts down the computer

title: If superpowers were real: Invisibility - Joy Lin

multiple-choice.question: If you were invisible, why would you have to be totally naked to move around undetected by other people?

options.label: A
options.text: Because clothes would make you visible to the human eye.

options.label: B
options.text: Because clothes would make noise while you move.

options.label: C
options.text: Because clothes would carry scents that people could smell.

options.label: D
options.text: Because clothes and objects on you would be visible even if you are not.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if someone accidentally spills scolding hot coffee on you while you're invisible?

options.label: A
options.text: The coffee would pass through you without any effect.

options.label: B
options.text: The coffee would make you visible to the human eye.

options.label: C
options.text: The coffee would not affect your invisibility in any way.

options.label: D
options.text: The coffee would make you feel pain but not affect your invisibility.

multiple-choice.question: Why would dust make you visible even if you're invisible?

options.label: A
options.text: Because dust sticks to the moisture on your skin when you sweat.

options.label: B
options.text: Because dust is attracted to invisible objects.

options.label: C
options.text: Because dust is made up of tiny particles that can see through invisibility.

options.label: D
options.text: Because dust is only visible on invisible objects.

multiple-choice.question: Why wouldn't you be able to see if you're invisible?

options.label: A
options.text: Because your eyes would be closed while you're invisible.

options.label: B
options.text: Because light would travel through you or around you instead of bouncing off you.

options.label: C
options.text: Because your brain would be unable to interpret images while you're invisible.

options.label: D
options.text: Because your retinas would be damaged by the invisibility.

multiple-choice.question: What would be a major problem if everyone was permanently invisible?

options.label: A
options.text: It would be difficult to communicate with each other.

options.label: B
options.text: It would be difficult to receive medical treatment from a doctor.

options.label: C
options.text: It would be a lonely and boring world without seeing people.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

title: If superpowers were real: Flight - Joy Lin

multiple-choice.question: According to Newton's Third Law of Motion, what happens when we run and push against the ground with our feet?

options.label: A
options.text: The ground gets out of the way.

options.label: B
options.text: The ground pushes back and propels us forward.

options.label: C
options.text: The ground stays still and does not react.

options.label: D
options.text: The ground pulls us backward.

multiple-choice.question: Why is Michael Phelps' fastest recorded swimming speed less than 5 miles per hour, despite being the fastest human in water?

options.label: A
options.text: Because water is denser than air.

options.label: B
options.text: Because water molecules can slide past each other instead of pushing back.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Phelps is not trying his best.

options.label: D
options.text: Because swimming is not as efficient as running.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to the inert gas in your body if you were to fly straight up too quickly?

options.label: A
options.text: It would rapidly contract.

options.label: B
options.text: It would rapidly expand.

options.label: C
options.text: It would stay the same.

options.label: D
options.text: It would disappear.

multiple-choice.question: According to the Ideal Gas Law, what happens to pressure and temperature as altitude increases?

options.label: A
options.text: Pressure increases and temperature decreases.

options.label: B
options.text: Pressure decreases and temperature increases.

options.label: C
options.text: Pressure and temperature both increase.

options.label: D
options.text: Pressure and temperature both decrease.

multiple-choice.question: Why would you need to wrap yourself up to keep your core body temperature above 95 degrees Fahrenheit if you were flying above the clouds?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the atmospheric pressure is higher at high altitudes.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the atmospheric pressure is lower at high altitudes.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the air is denser at high altitudes.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the air is warmer at high altitudes.

title: If superpowers were real: Immortality - Joy Lin

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how many days would a person live if they live until they're 82 years old?

options.label: A
options.text: 10,000 days

options.label: B
options.text: 20,000 days

options.label: C
options.text: 30,000 days

options.label: D
options.text: 40,000 days

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential problem with an immortal person's memory, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: They would remember every single detail of their past.

options.label: B
options.text: They would forget everything from their past.

options.label: C
options.text: They would have a limited capacity and replace useless memories with relevant information.

options.label: D
options.text: They would not be able to form new memories.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what would happen to the average height of humans if women find taller men more attractive and there are no natural disasters that wipe out all the tall people?

options.label: A
options.text: The average height would decrease over time.

options.label: B
options.text: The average height would remain the same over time.

options.label: C
options.text: The average height would increase over time.

options.label: D
options.text: The average height would fluctuate randomly over time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential physical consequence of immortality mentioned in the transcript, besides scars?

options.label: A
options.text: Losing all body hair.

options.label: B
options.text: Becoming invincible.

options.label: C
options.text: Losing limbs or other body parts due to accidents or illnesses.

options.label: D
options.text: Staying physically youthful forever.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the approximate number of amputation-related hospital discharges every year in the U.S.?
